Posts.Content: Hi Clare Sorry to hear your news. I can understand how fed up you are and you've got some good advice here. A positive thing that springs to my mind is that you are being carefully monitored by your breast care team and although its not great they ave found something, hopefully they have found it early and you can get successful treatment. Sending you good luck, love and best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Cannot move forward

Posts.Content: Hi No Herceptin or hormone drugs for me as I'm triple neg. finished chemo in August and still getting bone ache. Am told this is normal. Like others say some days can hardly move and stretching out makes it better.  Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Pain in joints and muscles

Posts.Content: Hi Gina When you have had time to take it in, and hopefully the messages on here have given you faith that cancer can be overcome, make up your mind that you will get through this with the love and support of those around you and on this site.  The results will come soon enough and then you can start your journey to recovery.   In the meantime, you might want to write down some questions for your appointment, you can often forget these in the moment and then fret afterwards. Until your appointment, be nice to yourself and do things that make you happy with your family. Good luck and please come back and let us know how you get on. Nadjie PS:  I started my journey in February, lymph node removal, mastectomy and reconstruction and last chemo on 12 August.  It goes very quickly :-)
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed and terrified.

Posts.Content: :-)  I wish we had a "like" button :-)  Well done littlesusie.
Posts.Title: A big step today

Posts.Content: Hi I took a hair and nail supplement and rubbed coconut oil in.  All good now.
Posts.Title: Eye brow regrowth.

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky I had side effects for about 8 weeks after my last T on 12 August. The Onc when I saw him on 2 October said they could last up to a year - I am sure they won't I had terrible bone pains all over.  breathlessness and swelling of my wrists and ankles and bloating of my stomach. They've all gone now but a couple of weeks ago I lost two toenails and my fingers nails are still horrific. I would raise it with your radiologist so you can check if you are ok to go ahead with treatment.
Posts.Title: Do the side effects of 'T' return after last round?

Posts.Content: Thanks Nikki Stay with it, you will feel better soon.
Posts.Title: Do the side effects of 'T' return after last round?

Posts.Content: Hi Sister Snail I know George has provided the links to the chemo drugs. But in the breast cancer group we also did a couple of lists on hints and tips for chemo, although this is based around the chemo drugs for breast cancer.  Some of the information is generic and you might find it helpful for your Dad. Here are the links. Good luck.  Nadjie http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2015/04/13/what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-two.aspx   http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2015/04/10/what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-one.aspx
Posts.Title: Confused daughter

Posts.Content: Hiya.  Radiotherapy is mostly the treatment offered when you have a lumpectomy and/or cancer cells are in the lymph nodes.  You dont always need radiotherapy if you have a mastectomy as the whole breast has been removed and radiotherapy is a more localised treatement.   If you have a mastectomy and are likely to need radiotheraphy then an immediate reconstruction is not advised as this can interfere with the treatment.  I had a masecttomy with immediate reconstruction and no cancer present in my lymph nodes so my post surgery treatement is chemotherapy.  I might not have needed chemotherapy but as I an triple negative, I can't have hormonal treatement such as tamoxifen.  It is a lot to learn in a short space of time when you are still trying to come to terms with it all.  What I tend to do is a bit of reading before my appoinment and then write some questions down.  If you take someone with you, you can ask them to remind you if you forget to ask.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: silly question time !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Sister-Snail Sorry to hear about your Dad, researching and understanding what;s happening to him will help you support your Mum and Dad. It is a minefield, and a lot of take in when its someone close to you. Your Dad sounds like a tough cookie and he's got a very caring daughter to take care of him. Good luck. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Confused daughter

Posts.Content: Hi Pink, As the others have said.  Feeling this way is perfectly normal. I finished treatment in October.  My Oncologist said if you have any symptoms for a month then seek help - that helped me put it into perspective.  Also, I have done the Macmillan HOPE course and am doing the Breast Cancer Care Moving Forward course.  Check out the websites for more details.  You may find these helps you as they tackle the "what next" feelings. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Everything spells cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Worcesterhobo I looked at it a bit differently. After having mastectomy and with the thought of chemo I thought the cold cap was a step too far. So I shaved my hair off and embraced a totally new look with hats and scarves. I did have two wigs but hated them !    See how you feel and be prepared as the cold cap doesn"t work for everyone
Posts.Title: FEC-T and Cold Cap

Posts.Content: Ps:  not sure what the normal time period is between temporary and permanent implants. Mine was that time as I had to have chemo in between.
Posts.Title: Falling to pieces

Posts.Content: Hi Little Miss Organised I had expander recon in one breast last March and permanent implant in October.  It will get better and speak to your medical team if the pain becomes unbearable. Also some nerve sensation does come back the top area of my breast has feeling although it is numb at the front. Did you have any lymph nodes removed as sometimes that can give you a bigger area of numbness.  It just feels part me now and doesn't feel odd. I have had massages and can lay on my front. As with my normal boob have to get a comfortable position but nothing a well positioned pillow can't sort out.  Take care and let me know if I can help.
Posts.Title: Falling to pieces

Posts.Content: Hi JRIP Remember me from July Chemo Club So, I'm TNBC and I'm going to be a survivor !  I'm not young, 55 and I had two tumours one at the nipple and one at the chest wall, its having clear margins from the tumour that are important.  Plus, although we can't have hormonal treatments, TNBC responds very well to chemo and I think of it as if the chemo tough then its doing its job.  So i am 3 x FEC done and Day 7 of first T.  I don't know that its been harder than FEC, but I think the risk of infection is higher and of course you've had chemo treatment already thas has weakened your body's defences so I think we must not underestimate the importance of taking care of ourselves while on T. So, you will get through it ! Nadjie
Posts.Title: Triple negative survivors , taxotere survivors shout out

Posts.Content: Hi Mary-Anne Sorry about your diagnosis. They were able to see my cancer on the ultrasound. I was diagnosed a year ago - two tumours and multifocal cells. Stage 1 grade3 no lymph node involvement. Mastectomy and chemo all done. Please feel free to ask me any questions.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results

Posts.Content: Thanks George aka Dreamthief   This is really helpful as I will be seeing the Oncologist for the first time on 13 April.
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors - All Brands of The 4 Hormonal Therapy Table...

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone I finished chemo in August.  My fingernails have just grown out the riding.  Up until recently they were so painful, splitting all the time and catching on everything.  I never lost any fingernail.  I did lose 2 toenails (the big ones) in October.  These are taking an age to grow back.  Anyone got any experience of this or any ideas to encourage growth ? Thanks and best wishes to you all.
Posts.Title: Nails!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi JJ I had 3 x FEC and 3 x T. I found FEC ok. I had the nausea and a bit of fatigue but it felt like being pregnant and after a couple of days I was fine. I did find T hard. Like Julia about day 4 was worse. I had terrible fatigue and bone ache, constipation, diarrhoea, thrush and cystitus. The affects of chemo are cumaltive so you can naturally expect to feel a little worse as it goes on. That being said, its doable, just expect that your plans might go AWOL - the hardest bit for me. I had my last T on 12 August and still have side effects of muscle pain in my legs and arms and my toenail fell off yesterday. I have also had fluid retention and swelling on my face, wrists and ankles. I hope this doesn't sound too grim, it isn't, but i just like to tell it how it is :-) I did manage to do a 15 mile bike ride for Macmillan today :-) Best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects info please

Posts.Content: Hi Clare and Sam Clare, if the tumour(s) are large then chemotherapy is generally given before surgery to try and shrink them and minimise surgery. In some cases tumours have disappeared altogether. Sam,the thing about the node removal is that its an awkward place in your armpit. If you can, it will help your recovery quicker if you can rest with your arm away from your body as your arm will irritate your wound. Oh and do the exercises. I was diagnosed with Stage 1 Grade 3 triple negative breast cancer in February, i have had a mastectomy and reconstruction and sentinel node removal. I'm not having radiotherapy and had my last chemo on 12 August (I had 6). I can honestly say it wasn't as bad as i thought and it went really quickly. I remember how you felt Sam with it being in your head and it will stay like that. Its weird but its a bit like when you are pregnant and you can't stop thinking and talking about it. The good news is, you have been diagnosed and are being treated which means you are on the road to recovery. Keep well and don't be afraid to ask any questions. There are also a lot of publications on this site which are worth a read. The best advice I can give you is while you feel well, keep busy. And when you feel unwell accept that you need to rest, sometimes this won't be what you want or won't be convenient, but you just got to go with it. Best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: New to here

Posts.Content: Good for you Medusa.  I start my chemo MOnday week and am getting my hairdresser to shave mine off next Thursday :-)
Posts.Title: My hair has finally decided to leave the building!

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne.  I'm triple neg and finished my chemo on 12 August, I also had a mastectomy in March which my consultant was originally reluctant to do.  My Onc said that I didn;t need radiotherapy then, but I reviewed it with him again in October as there is no targeted therapy for me.  I am 55 and my perspective is that while I have good health I will take every treatment going.  Chemo is tough, but definitely doable and does the job when it comes to killing cancer cells. Good luck with whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX

Posts.Content: Hi everyone.  I am a breast cancer survivor - TNBC last year. Recently someone I met in a Hope course said I was high risk for ovarian cancer so I,veg just had a CA125 blood test done. Anyone got any experience or Gen on this or shall I pop into the Ovarian cancer group.  Cheers.
Posts.Title: CA125 blood test

Posts.Content: Good for you Medusa.  I start my chemo MOnday week and am getting my hairdresser to shave mine off next Thursday :-)
Posts.Title: My hair has finally decided to leave the building!

Posts.Content: Thanks Helen for your quick reply.  I know it's a snapshot and hopefully I will get a low reading and persuade my GP To run it as necessary. Trouble with the symptoms is they are fairly common in most women unfortunately.  I also had to have a smear test and had originally told me I didn't need them after my hysterectomy when in fact I do. Ho hum.  Will let you know how I get on.
Posts.Title: CA125 blood test

Posts.Content: Hey George Thanks for posting.  I hope you and Jackie are doing well. I am good.  I got loads of cycling planned this year as I've signed up to do Vietnam to Cambodia for Women V Cancer, and breast, ovarian and cervical cancer.  If we all raise £5,000 we will have raised half a million - wow !  Its next February and 300 miles so I'm busy building up the miles. Yes she knew I was TNBC, and it was a bit of passing comment.  I'm not stressed out about it, and will as Helen suggests talk my GP into period testing as appropriate.  I was a little concerned that they gave me wrong information about smear tests as apparently I do have a cervix !!!!!  But hopefully those lovely doses of Docetaxel killed off anything nasty around my body.   Thanks for the nudge about posting in the post treatment thread.  You are right I'm a bit overdue and need to wake everyone up.  I've been in touch with Amanda - Champamunid Chick, she's doing great and doing the Women V Cancer Ride the Night with me in May. I've read a lot of your posts giving great advice as always, keep up the good work.  Best wishes.
Posts.Title: CA125 blood test

Posts.Content: They normally only do one as the other is considered cosmetic surgery.  If you have an implant then the other breast is slightly lower.  I have this and it looks fine in bras and clothes.  You can have other reconstructions using body flesh which give a more natural droop.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: They normally only do one as the other is considered cosmetic surgery.  If you have an implant then the other breast is slightly lower.  I have this and it looks fine in bras and clothes.  You can have other reconstructions using body flesh which give a more natural droop.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: You can,t have an implant if you are having radiotherapy.
Posts.Title: DIEP flap or Implants... How to choose?

Posts.Content: Well done you for overcoming that tough moment. Cumatively each chemo gets worse, but positively its also a step towards the end. I had 3 x FEC and 3 x T, the last T was the hardest on 12 August but I feel better every day. Sending you best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: coming out of that dark tunnel.

Posts.Content: Morning everyone Vonnie and Lee sounds like you have a tougher ride with TC, I wish you all the best with that and Lee I'm glad you're out of hospital. Karin and Amanda its really helpful to here about your experience of T, especially for me as its my first one on 1 July. Mags, sounds like your super Mum is continuing to do well. Me, I am fine = thanks for asking Trish.  Day 3 FEC 3.  Nausea Day 1 but fine since then.  I am a bit tired but that's probably because I;m not really resting, but hey its the weekend :-) I hope you all have a great day and a symptom free weekend.  It looks like its going to be a scorcher today.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Trish and everyone. Definitely feeling the cumulative effects of FEC No 3 Day 4 on the tiredness front.  And last night no taste for my favourite fish and chips so onto the spicy food for a bit i think.  Yeah and the fuzzy head, my brain is forgetful enough !!!!  Going to try and make my bike ride tomorrow morning so I am not too lazy.  And so excited for next weekend when I go to LIverpool to visit one of my closest friends.  After 3 months in soft and cosmetic bras I am finally going to be able to go buy a new bra - woo hoo I can't wait.  We're going to a specialist shop in Southport.  And by then I hope to be able to have a few glasses of the white stuff too :-) Hope all the T girls are doing well and taking it easy.  To be honest you can't do much else in good old Essex as the weather is crap !   Keep smiling. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Sarahj48 Given your situation I am not surprised that you are considering a mastectomy.  I suspect you already know what you need to do. If you are considering an immediate reconstruction,  I had a mastectomy on 21 March with expander implant reconstruction and my experience has been a positive one.  The recovery was fine and if I had to have another one I would be ok about it.  After the initial hospital recovery, you will need to do exercises for several weeks and no heavy lifting.  This is critical to your full recovery.  Some of the other ladies on her can give you your their view on other reconstructions. Good luck. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Lee I was up to just before 2am last night and a few minutes longer and I could have replied straight away to your post.  Although my hair has been short for some 40 years (just no good at styling it long), it too has been my crowing glory with people always complimenting on it.  I chose not to have the cold cap and thought I would be hunky dory with it falling out.  Its been gone now for a month now.  I can completely understand how you feel.  Its horrible and the moulting is a constant reminder of what is to come.  Even though I had my cropped at the start of my chemo, it came out in droves about 2 weeks in and I did have a little cry when I saw myself bald. The soreness will go.  If you can rub in some coconut oil into your scalp (you can get from Holland and Barrett or Health Shops).  Its not expensive and last for ages, I bought a huge tub from Costco for a tenner. I bought a wig, but I have hardly worn it, as I find it a little hot.  I have bought a few cheap hats from Peacocks and Matalan for £6 each and they are great and look great too.  You might be able to wear them in combination with the remainder of your hair.  I've also got some sleep caps which I put bandanas around to dress them up (bought them cheap from Claire's accessories). Its weird as having short hair forever I've never worn these feminine things and I am now enjoying having a different style.  I'll try and post some pics that I hope will make you smile. I've also booked onto the Headstrong workshop on 6 July at Southend Hospital where they show you what to do with the headwear thing.  Here is the link and maybe you might like to book on at your nearest one. https://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/breast-cancer-services/talks-courses-local-support/hair-loss-advisory-service/headstrong-locations#london Hope you feel better today. Best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Good luck tomorrow Wendy and have a lovely day today with that roast dinner and good company. if its FEC that is your first (i've just had number 3), it was the nausea I found worse on the first one and the horrible taste in my mouth.  Helped a lot by loads of water, plenty of rest and spicy food. Best wishes to you. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Trish Glad you are feeling better. Am on the train now to LIverpool - woo hoo. Back on Tuesday night. Was at the Football Awards last night for my daughter who is 14 and she won Player of the Year so proud. One of the things that my cancer journey has bought me is a sheer enjoyment and pleasure of the small things and also remembering what are the important things. I don't think I would have had this realisation if I hadn't got breast cancer. I know it sounds really weird but I feel very happy and at peace with myself and life at the moment. Does anyone else feel like this, or this an effect of the chemo :-) !!!!! Have a great day. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Trish Thanks for posting this morning.  Yeah I think most of us are hitting a wall at the moment.  I was totally wiped out yesterday, could not get out of bed and I think it has been even tougher for some of the others.  How are you feeling Trish ? I think we need some of George's pictures to make us smile :-) No bike ride for me.  Resting up and hoping to feel better as the day goes on.  Definitely feel better than yesterday. Sending you all best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi bm84 and welcome. We're all going through (or supporting someone who is going through) chemo at the moment so you will get some comfort and answers to your questions.  It must have been a shock your diagnosis and then to have to move into fertility treatment, I hope that is going well. So, FEC-T is the most common chemo and is normally 6 treatments of 3 x FEC and then 3 X T at 3 week intervals.  I have just had no 3 FEC and you can find some useful info about chemo at the blogs we recently put together here. http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2015/04/10/what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-one.aspx   http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2015/04/13/what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-two.aspx You'll also find some factsheets on here for FEC and T and the side affects.  Everyone is different and you'll probably be able to learn from chemo no ! and apply it it no 2.  For me it was the nausea and metal taste so plenty of water and finding a food you can eat (normally spicey or strong flavour).  I would also advise you to start thinking about your hair, there are ladies on here who went for the cold cap which you have at the same time as chemo to help preserve your hair.  Either way you will need some headgear, scarves, bandanas, hats etc.  I've bought some cheap hats from Peacocks and Matalan for £6 and some bandanas from Claire's accessories.  I've found having a selection and feeling god about my appearance has helped me deal with the chemo. Wish you good luck. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hello Bunnies After a couple of off days with severe fatigue I am pleased to report that I am bouncy today. Day 8 FEC 3 and all is good. I even managed a bike today - yippee and signed up for WomenVsCancer Ride the Night 2016. I hope that I can cheer those having a tough time by letting you know that your kind donations contribution to me raising to date an astounding £2152.77.  The total raised by all 2000 women that took part is nearing a £1m which will go towards helping the causes of breast, ovarian and cervical cancer. Thank you - you amazing group of people. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Karin I loved the ice cream joke too ! Chrissy, I'm two days after you on T, starting Wednesday and Trish is just after me.  No Herceptin for me as Triple Neg. Good luck on Monday. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Karin So good to have you back.   You are such a colourful character in this community and so supportive of others so any absence in the chat is immediately noticeable, oh and course we miss the jokes :-)  That's what this site is all about, looking out for and supporting each other. Really pleased you are feeling better. Have a great day today. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hey Amanda Good to see you're getting through T ok.  Hopefully the booster for haemoglobin will give you "Lance Armstrong-like" strength :-) Had a fab time in Liverpool but very knackered when I got back. I'm the proud owner of 4 new bra's.  Feel like I've had a body lift :-)  so good to wear a bra that supports me.  I have gone up two cup sizes from 38b to 38d - must be all the chocolate !! But the best thing is that my new boob is the same size as my other one - woo hoo ! Quick question on T - is there any need to take anti-sickness ?   I normally take this the day before FEC. Cheers and have a great evening. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: HI Hev That is great news - congratulations for your strength and perseverence, I know it hasn't always been easy. Wishing you the best of luck for the next phase of your treatment and looking forward to seeing that new boob :-) !!! Have a great day. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda I think I might take an anti-sickness on the day just in case. Yeah I've got to take double dose steroids starting one day before T. Thanks. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hey Trish Yeah goodbye to FEC !!!!! T on 1 `July for me. I'm not having any Herceptin or Tamoxifen etc as I'm triple negative. I'll let you know on 1 July how the T goes. Hope you are doing ok. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone - loving the long posts. Happy Birthday Mags, I hope you had a chance to relax and enjoy your special day. Trish, great news on your bloods, good luck tomorrow. FEC No 3 today and I feel so so, I stayed a bit longer at the hospital and took my antisickness before today, but definitely got a bit of nausea and stomach ache going on, but no nasty taste or other problems a the moment. Re: all the other discussion.  Really admire those that have done the cold cap, i'm definitely a bit of a baby so didn't even try it.  now i have the problem of a short wig that is already hot  so have bought some hats and signed up for the headstrong workshop as i'm not very good at the scart thing.  Here's the link in case you thinkg it might be useful  for you. http://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/breast-cancer-services/talks-courses-local-support/hair-loss-advisory-service/headstrong-locations Advice I have had is no painkillers without consultation with BCN or hospital team. It seems like we're a bit split on experience of FEC vs T.   My view is FEC has definitely not been as bad as I thought so lets see what T brings.  I asked today how long my T ttreatment will take on 1 July and they said 1 hour but that might be down to the Port, more on that below.  I wonder also if whatever treatment you have the second half is worse because you have had more treatments and a cumulative build up of chemo drugs. Like Amanda I have a port, its called a Bard Power Port - will post a link when I find one - i'll try and post a picture too.  Like Amanda said its inserted beneath the chest skin and has a line down towards your heart.  I will give you my view on it, and it is only my view. The great advantage is that your drugs - and everything intraveneous can be given through it, are much much quicker, my FEC today took 10 minutes.  They can also take your bloods from it.  It is more expensive than other line methods so may not be offered by all hospitals but it is worth asking about. after you've done a little research and can convience your BC team that its better for you (and them :-)).  The cons, the first couple of weeks i kept feeling a dragging pain when i moved (but lets face it i don't sit still) this was my lack of understanding about recovery after insertion and that it was inserted on my good side (ie it couldn't go on my right side where i had had my mastectomy) and my left side had been getttng more movement.  Now I've got used to it and am more aware of movemens that give me a little twinge like big upward stretches of my left arm.  Oh and i couldnt forget the other hair discussion.  So hair all gone, eyebrows gone, eyelashes still in intact, didnt have much hair on arms and legs.  look away George - hair on foofoo partially gone. Keep well everyone. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Personally Krispy Kreme doughnuts don't do it for me.  I like proper bakers doughnuts, especially the giant ones you get a bootsales and county shows.  Ditto for Subway, although my kids seem to like them.  I can tell you though that the Krispy Kreme doughnut is doom as it contains equal amounts of fat and sugar making then very moreish to those that like them :-) Hope I haven't spoiled anyones appetite ! Have a great evening.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hey Trish How are you feeling today ?  I hope you are feeling better.  God that fatigue is killer isn't it.  What got me out of it on Tuesday evening when I had had three days of it was to go out for a walk in the evening.  Hopefully you have somewhere nice you can walk to. I just needed to get past it as I'm going to Liverpool on Sunday to visit my very good friend and we're going to Southport on Tuesday to a specialist bra shop and I'm going to buy a new bra(s).  I haven't wore a proper bra since 9 March so am so excited :-) Hope everyone else is doing better today, both those more advanced in their chemo and the new chemoers, and that you all have a good day. Best wishes. Nadjie PS:  I must apologise for my appalling grammar - one of the awful side affects.  I make sure I read what I write and then when I read it after its still full of errors - hopefully you're all in the same state and don't notice it :-)  aaarrrgggghhhh to chemo brain !

Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Everyone Amanda, thanks for good info on Manuka. Chrissie, I'm right behind you with my 3rd FEC tomorrow. Onco appointment today. Karin and Trish, hope you guys are doing ok. Mags, how is is Regina ? Oh and Birty I forgot to mention about nails. I have used dark nail paint and hardner but my nails are very week at the top and splitting all the time. I just try to keep them short to stop them catching and splitting even more. Have a great day everyone. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Ceskypesky So sorry to hear you lost your Mother-in-law.  Even though 90 is a good age, its always very hard, especially when you have your own fight to deal with.  I hope that you will reflect on happy memories and I am sure her legacy will live on. Best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: here is the link to the patient guide for my Power port http://www.bardaccess.com/powerportadvantage/assets/pdfs/0723905_09-225_PowerPort_Patient_Guide_web.pdf I'm going to post two pictures the first so you can see the position - still have dressing on from today and the second with dressing off. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hope you are feeling ok Amanda. To put it into perspective. My FEC is administered in 3 giant syringes. But I also have something in a drip bag, I think its an antibiotic. So when you had that on it takes around an hour. The T is not administered in a syringe, it is in a drip bag so I reckon in total it will be about 2 hours. I have no idea what my doses are, but my Onco did say I was on the highest dose when I asked him as I had vascular invasion and of course am Triple Neg and not having radiotherapy. I have no idea what Paclitaxel is, sorry. Keep well. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning ! Karin, I can't remember what I asked either, but I do remember that you answered it :-) Hev, glad you've made a decision about your reconstruction and I hope it all goes well for you. Good advice too about taking your time about making the decision.  The only thing I will say on balance is that if you leave it too long you might not do it, and maybe that's the right thing too. Because I had surgery first I did have to make a fairly quick decision on my reconstruction.  Having an immediate one was easy for me, my Mum had a mastectomy in 2007 at the age of 65 and has never got round to a reconstruction. I have fat on my stomach and back and even though I'm brave on certain things, I was a bit of a scaredy cat on that reconstruction so chose the implant with expander.  I have to say I am really pleased with it.  The recovery and pain was doable and when I bought my new bras the new boob fitted perfectly into them.  I think when my chemo is over I might have to have the implant replaced. On the cycling, I have to say its really helped me stay positive.  When I'm riding through the countryside I forget all my worries, and because its mostly my legs doing the work, I've been able to get back into it.  I do get bad days and I do know I should probably be resting more, but I've always had ants in my pants and I recognise that if my body says stop I will (got hubby on standby to pick me up if I have to bail out of the bike ride on Saturday :-)). I echo what Hev has been saying about the time it takes to go through this journey.  When I was diagnosed in February it seemed like a life time and now Chemo No 4/6 is tomorrow.  I'll also be joined at my session by a man who will be on his last Herceptin so its the end of his treatment.  I don't know what his cancer is, but he's had surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy and Herceptin, am going to take a little cake down to celebrate.  One thing I will say is the best therapy for my cancer journey has been here.  As they used to say on the BT adverts - "its good to talk". Have a great day. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Karin Glad you are starting to feel better. For your mouth and taste.  Spicy food when you can't taste anything or stronger tasting food might help you enjoy your food by it tasting better.  When I had my favourite fish and chips on friday it was like eating cardboard so I've ramped up the flavours.  You can rinse your mouth with salt walter or bicarbonate of soda mixed in a litttle water as these both help too.  Plus using non-alccohol mouthwashes.   The nails is a problem.  Mine are splitting and flaking terrible.  I just keep putting on vitamin e oil at night (very cheap to buy from superdrug) and making sure they are painted with nail hardener.  I know they are going to get worse when I have my first T on 1 July. Wish you a great day.  I just had a mammoth sleep and am going to attempt some light housework and take it easy today. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Birty Sorry to hear you are having a tought time.  But hopefully you are on the mend now.  I lost my hair around the same time as you.  Just had my third FEC.  You could get a hat if you can't do a scarf.  I got myself a couple of cheap summer ones from Matalan and Peacocks at `£6 a go they are great.   Can;t advise on the hickman unfortunately, but maybe someone else can. wish you bettter. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hey Amanda Congratulations on 23 years, I'm just behind you at 22 years :-) I've booked for the 9.30pm wave as I think the 9.00pm is full now. When you sign up. Choose to join and team and choose "Midnight Breeze" which is the group where some of my other cycling friends are in. I'm really looking forward to cycling with you. Its a great route and there is only one hill in it. Have a great day. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: I agree Amanda There are definitely some "friends" that are no longer "friends" thats for sure and I have been astounded with some behaviour and lack of sensitivity and support. Regarding my new boob. Well my reconstruction happened real quick, I was diagnosed on 27 Feb and had it on 21 March so didn't have much time to think about it. What I can say, is that I never imagined today that I would say, it feels like a natural part of my body. It doesn't feel like it doesn't belong or any different to my other breast (except that its a big perkier !!!). Of course when you first get it, you are very aware and conscious of it, but now I don't even think about it. In a couple of months I'll have the option to have a nipple tattooed and I'm thinking about having a smiley face instead so it reminds me of what I been through and how lucky I am. Any other suggestions of alternatives to nipple tattoo very welcome !!!! I've said this before and sorry to lecture you Hev and everyone else yet to have reconstruction. It is really really important to do the exercises. Even when you don't want to and feel a bit stiff and sore. Because I was a bit crazy about doing the WomenVsCancer bike ride I was religous about them and the result speak for themselves. I am 100% back to normal re mobility, movement etc and I have no numbness in my arm whatsoever. Its a great feeling. Best wishes to you all. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Dorothy  I've had 3 x FEC.  The nausea gets easier if you take the anti-sickness the day before chemo.  I've found FEC 2 and 3 easier but the cumulative affects for me were in fatigue for FEC 3.  I will have 3 x T from 1 July. You can sign up here for a Headstrong worksho if you fancy it where they help you to do headgear and scarves etc. http://www.lookgoodfeelbetter.co.uk/workshops-and-advice/dates-and-locations Good luck. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda I meant to say re your port.  Don't let them rush to take it out.  Hopefully you won't need it, but you never know. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Daffodil11 and welcome Here are the blogs recently contributed to by others that you should find helpful. http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2015/04/10/what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-one.aspx   http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/community_news/archive/2015/04/13/what-should-i-bring-to-my-chemo-part-two.aspx If you look through the previous posts you will see from tips re hair/cold cap.  If the cold cap is available to you tomorrow and you want to preserve your hair then see what others say on this.  I did not use it and advice from me and Amanda if you're not using the cold cap is get your hair cut real short as it will start falling out in about 10 days. FEC-T is the most common breast cancer chemo treatment.  I have had 3 cycles of it and for the first treatment the nausea will probably be the worse.  Drink plenty of water and rest up. Good luck. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Thanks Amanda for the great advice. It is good to get the chemo brain discussion out in the open, because as you point out it could have disasterous consequences. I still have my port in too, but I'm hoping to get a bra that I can adjust the straps around it.  My bra size was 38b so for me its just about getting better support.  I've been nagging my BC nurse for months and she finally said all systems go so that's it :-)  I know you've got a lean ;physique so hopefully you are not suffering the bra syndrome too much. Have a great day in Portugal - we're enjoying similar weather here in the UK :-) Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Chrissie I should have said, I've had hysterectomy and two C-sections so my stomach was no good and it would have all had to come from my back. When you look at my implant when I'm naked, its definitely perkier than my other boob, but I am 55 so to be expected.  I do know you get a more natural shape in keeping with your other boob with the LD back flap and the feel of the boob is more natural if they use all of your tissue for the breast reconstruction.  When I touch my implant in my bra, it feels the same.  When I touch it naked it is different because it's not tissue.  That wasn't important to me because that breast has no feeling so my hubby wasn't going to be touching it in intimate moments anyway and I'm fine with how it feels to touch. If  you send me a private message, I would be happy to send you some photos. It was pretty much Hobson's choice for me, but it seems like you may have two choices.  In which case, I would do a little table with a list of what you would like the outcome to be and then check this against the two different reconstructions with pros/cons based on what you know and you can use this as a review with your consultant. Best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Good luck to everyone having treatment today. Bloods today for me, Onco tomorrow and T number 1 on Wednesday - all being well. Karin, you're having a second wind with the jokes, love them ! Hev, I have GCSF, I have it 24 hours after chemo in my stomach, but have been self-administering it.  Not sure if it continues with T. Have a great day everyone. Nadjie PS:  I am planning on doing a 100 mile ride with my cycling club on Saturday - am I mad or what :-)
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: thanks Amanda, the GCSF I have is called Neulasta and its says it stimulates bone marrow and white blood cells.   I checked with my BCN today and she said they will continue on T. Hope you are doing ok. Nadjie
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Definitely, where has June gone !  Thanks Amanda.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Linz. What drugs are you on for your chemo ? Also you may want to pop into the August chemo club discussion where you will get support from others going through chemo. There will be a new discussion thread for September starting up if not already there. At the start of the discussion you'll find links to a couple of chemo blogs with tips on how to get through chemo. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Chemo advice please

Posts.Content: Hi Cristobel Come and take a look in the July chemo club where you'll be in touch with loads of others that are having chemo at the moment. Nadjie
Posts.Title: New to all this!

Posts.Content: Hi Mags As Helen says, the stage/grade thing is confirmed after surgery.  Sometimes you can an initial diagnosis prior to surgery but this can be unreliable. I am also TNBC.  Usually the grading is 3 (as is mine) with TNBC, but not always. Here is some info below in the link on stage/grading which I hope will help. http://www.nhs.uk/chq/Pages/3169.aspx?CategoryID=96
Posts.Title: Stage after chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Bubbleblower.  welcome to the group.  I was diagnosed on 27 Feb so a relative newby.  I 've had a mastectomy and reconstruction and wiaiting to start chemo.  `It is a shock and most people view having cancer as a bad thing.  The good news is that you will now be treated to recovery.  Do you know the  the stage and grade of your cancer  ?  If not you must ask at your appointment.  Have a look on the macmillian site and get some information on what questions to ask.  You will also want to explore treatment options, so being  a little better informed will help you ask the right questions.  Tell your family that you are going to be fine and believe that to yourself.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Fab news Mags, we are on a roll with good news. Love and best wishes to you and Regina. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Good news! Mum got the all clear after surgery!

Posts.Content: Hi Mags. No more treatment for me as I'm not having rads and surgery all done:-)
Posts.Title: Good news! Mum got the all clear after surgery!

Posts.Content: All good thanks Mags. Chemo finished on 12 August for me and thats it all done. Just recovering from the side effects and aches and pains now. Best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Good news! Mum got the all clear after surgery!

Posts.Content: Best wishes Pat. Are you having a reconstruction ? You are on your way to recovery and this is a big step along that road. Good luck and make sure you do the exercises religously even when you don't feel like it. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Mastectomy tomorrow, 9-9-15

Posts.Content: shouldnt affect it at all  good luck
Posts.Title: Silly question

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz.  I had a scan before my sentinel node biopsy and mastctomy with reconstruction.  They do them so the have a clearer view of the cancer and are standard procedure.  As Mags says they take about 10 days.  I had mine on the MOnday and saw the consultant on the Thursday of the following week.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Scans

Posts.Content: Hi Invisble me The waiting is the pits, but find nice things to do to take your mind off it.  The great news is that you are being treated and are going to get better. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Told yesterday i have breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Lelly.  Be there to support your sister and to listen to her.  She will really appreciae having someone to talk to.  I don't have a twin, but am very close to my sister and we are 51 weeks apart in age.  Its terrible for everyone and for your sister i am sure it will upset her if she thinks you are upset so try and stay strong for her.  As George aka Dreamthief has said the online library is absolutely brilliant for information.   have a read throgh and it will help you understand what is going on.  I am sure your sister has done the same too.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Am I allowed to join - or would you prefer this group to be just patients...

Posts.Content: Hi George You are so thoughtful and I am always expressed by your support and excellent memory :-) I am doing fine thanks.  Getting stronger all the time although .I have had some relapses.  I didn't get a place in Ride London 100 but I have replied to Amanda's post I am doing Ride the Night again on Saturday and they've increased the distance to 64 miles.  I am not sure if you remember Amanda from Portugal (Champandick Chick - or something like that ).  Well she has come over to do the ride two and we will be meeting for the first time on Saturday :-)  I can't wait.  I will post some picks in the Life after treatment thred. I will be doing a 100 miler at the end of June and Vietnam to Cambodia in February 2017 - I think that's enough to keep me busy for now.  I hope you and Jackie are doing well thank you again for your support.
Posts.Title: 2 post mastectomy reconstruction bras to give away free

Posts.Content: Hi Alicurr.  I am sorry you have had such disappointing news.  I have to say that I've never heard of being too thin for implants (not that I suffer from that problem myself :-)) .  I had a two stage expander reconstruction 3 weeks ago.  Were you offered this type of reconstruction ?  If not it may be worth discussing this with your consultant or BCN.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: TUG free flap breast reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi.  I have two Anita Compression Bras size 38b/c from when I had my mastectomy and immediate reconstruction. They are in good nick and usually cost £115 each.  If they would be any good for you - please check with your breast care team first - then drop me a friend request and/or private message and will get them over to you free of charge.  A small donation to my just giving site to cover postage would be appreciated.   Hopefully I can do someone a favour.  Here is a link to a pic of the bra.  Compression bra
Posts.Title: 2 post mastectomy reconstruction bras to give away free

Posts.Content: Thanks Helen. I've see your bra type. Do they use them just for double mastectomies ?  I had just my right side done.
Posts.Title: 2 post mastectomy reconstruction bras to give away free

Posts.Content: Excellent.  Thanks  Jess.
Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute   Hi Some suggestions below from members of things that work and help during chemo.  I thought it could be helpful to repost both as a separate discussion and in the current month’s Chemo club.  Please can you continue to add your comments and suggestions also and I will update.  Recommendations on use of these items, brands/where to buy etc would be great too.  Thank you and good luck J  Digital thermometer (Lloyds pharmacy do a good one for £11) A good chlorhexidine mouthwash.  Mouthwash at least twice a day (eg Corsodyl non-alcoholic) Microwaveable Lavender wheat wrap for arm/vein aches. Manuka Honey (Aldi or H&B often do 2for1).  If you are on Doxcetaxel / Taxotere - get the Manuka 24+ from H&B if you can afford it as the higher the number the more pure it is. Soft toothbrush - Boots do a good baby electric toothbrush Ginger Nut Biscuits and/or Ginger Beer to help kick start taste buds. Pineapple cooled in the fridge to help with unpleasantness and stickiness inside mouth. Anti Nausea medication – really important to take this before you need it and consistently to keep on top of it.  Try to get medication prescribed before chemo starts. Avoid dairy products the day of treatment and a whilst you feel nauseous -including milk substitutes like almond, rice milk etc. But eat what you feel like, when you feel like it and don’t feel guilty as there will be so many things you won’t be able to eat either because they are on the list to avoid or you go off them Mouth Ulcers - make your diet as Alkaline as possible, avoid acid foods such as Oranges, blueberries, cranberries....instead eat melon, kiwi fruit, mango, apples....there are loads if good websites outlining acid/alkaline foods. Rinse out your mouth after meals with bicarbonate of soda.....change to a soft toothbrush, you can gently floss your teeth but don't use dental brushes. Get a gentle PH balanced soap and moisturiser for you skin - moisturise frequently....use rubber gloves for any "wet" work...don't have too many hot showers....drys your skin more.  Also plastic gloves for all cooking to protect hands, plus loads of hand cream. Clarins is good, although pricey lasts for ages and moisturises hands well Rest as you need to but exercise as frequently as possible - you might feel knackered but exercise will help battle the fatigue. Don't become a hermit - yes avoid circumstances/people you know to be ill.......but try to live as normal a life as possible.....it helps fight off any emotional side effects. Cold Sore Cream 100% organic almond oil for head when bald.  keeps hydrated and encourages hair growth when chemo finishes. Gingins from H&B. Ginger sweets, quite chewy but you can also suck them. Good for when saline or chemo going through you to take away initial weird taste. Ginger beer is very useful as an alcohol substitute... It didn't taste of metal and looked like a proper drink! Nail strengthener/varnish.  Nail oil to keep nails as health as possible - avocado oil quite cheap and lasts.  Dark nail polish is recommended to protect your nails during chemo. under eye concealer A place on a look good feel better course- apply ASAP as it can take a while to get on one Huggies-fragrance free baby wipes - very useful for all sorts of things!!! Keep a Diary.... Not only for appointments – With enough page space to write in how you feel on a daily basis and to record temperature readings. Keep important telephone nos. and notes handy that family, friends, helpers can access if  you’re feeling poorly. Keep a clothes kit ready for emergency dash to hospital. Moist toilet wipes - Tesco sensitive or Andrex - really helpful if you are very dry. 'Emend' tablets off Doctor are brilliant for sickness 'Rasberry Mucilage' off Doctor to ease throat problems Caphasol or Difflam off Doctor for Mouth rinsing and both clean mouth of any germs. Lockets for throat. Plastic cutlery as meal can taste awful. Wigs on Amazon under “Mistresses” so natural looking. Sleeping caps to keep your head warm at night. Phone “Headstrong” for ideas on scarves
Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: Hi, If you are coming to the end of chemo and want to join the life after chemo club.  Here is the link. RE: --------------- Post treatment club (life after breast cancer treatment) ----------------  Good luck.   Nadjie
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Jackie Those that had T first said it was easier than FEC. I had FEC first and like you sailed through.  there is no doubt that T was harder (I had three with my last one on 12 August), but it seems harder because FEC was so easy.  Take it that T is how chemo is supposed to be.  It is tough, but still doable and don't make any plans and rest up. Day 4 to 14 tend to the worse. Best wishes. Nadjie
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thank you very much Clair that is really kind of you.  My immediate concern is what to ask the Oncologist on Tuesday.  I will be asking him why radiotherapy is not proposed as my breast cancer surgeon told me that is what they have agreed.  I did have a small tumour close to the chest wall so I want to check that there were clear margins.  I also want to ask him about BRACA testing as I understand that TNBC has a higher link to genetic cancer.  My Mum had BC in 2007 and I have a 14 year old daughter to consider.  Is there anything else I should ask the Oncologist ? PS:  I am 2.5 weeks post mastectomy with expander reconstruction and would be happy to share my experience of that if it would help you.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks George. I have added Clair as a friend.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi.  I got my results today from my mastectomy.  I have a Stage 1 / Grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma, two tumours removed.  The lab path tests proved negative for ER/PR and HER2.  No cancer cells found in my lymph nodes.  Next treatment is chemo and i see the Oncologist next Tuesday.  I know that i'm not suitable for hormone therapy but don't really know whtat TNBC means or what questions I should ask the Oncologist. Anyone got any experience they can pass on please ? Cheers.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia and Mysteryleo.  This is very helpful.  I am 55 so pretty old to have TNBC.  I feel more confident about my Oncology appoinment now I have your replies.  regrding the actual hard data on my ER/PR/HER2, should I be given, can I request a copy of this report as at present I don't have this.  My daugher is 14 so useful to know that she needs to be 18 for any genetic testing.  Both my maternal Grandfather and Uncle died from lung cancer (not sure if this counts as they were both smokers).  My Mum had breast cancer in 2007.  I hadn't even thought about genetic testing my consultant said that there may be a link between TNBC and BRAC1. Great news about the trial too, well done for agreeing to do that.    Not long till Tuesday. ......  Thanks again and best wishes to you all.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks George, I will seek out Birty and the TNBC group.  Yes, I've definitely got a mental age of below 40 :-).  Just a bit worried that there is a lack of drug treatment and return/survival for TNBC but I do know that it responds to chemo well.  Am very lucky its not in my lymph nodes and hoping for an inspiring discussion with the Oncologist on Tuesday.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Katee.  I had my mastectomy and reconstruction a month ago.  Aside of the exercises, which are a must, I find that some days it looks less swollen, feels less painful, than previous.  I too can feel the swelling at the side.  Like you been told this is normal.  Also, when you look at it in comparison, try to do so by holiding your other one up level and also, look at it in a bra, because seeing it straight on naked can distort what it really looks like.  I'm going to start mssaging mine too, unless I can find a rich and gorgeous man to do it for me :-)
Posts.Title: Swollen arm/breast is it normal?

Posts.Content: HI Don;t be too hasty about your hair and the cold cap.  I know from others experiences that in areas where the cap wasn't a tight fit that you can loose your hair in that area.  If its falling out then give it a good wash so you get past the moulting.  I would definitely give it to your next chemo and see how you go. Most of us that didn't do the cold cap went cold turkey when it started falling out and had it clippered off :-) Good luck. Nadjie
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Ask for an immediate appointment, your GP should then refer you the breast cancer clinic and you will be seen within 2 weeks. Failing that if you have a GP out of ours service at your local hospital, phone them and insist on being seen immediately. Your partner knows your well and he is done you a massive favour telling you this. Go get it sorted and good luck.
Posts.Title: Don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Hi Kaz Docetaxel is a pig.  I just finished my third and final on 12 August.  Its a lot worse than FEC.  The side effects are greater and you will likely get many of them.  Tingling/Numbness in feet and hands, diarrhoea, constipation, thrush - oral and vaginal - pains in hips and legs, fatigue, lost of appetitte, loss of taste (furry mouth), fungal nail infection, cough, colds and flu like symptoms, shortness of breath. The good news is that the all fade from the second week of treatment. Good luck, it will all be over soon enough :-) Nadjie
Posts.Title: Docytexal

Posts.Content: HI Morecombe As Dreamthief says, come join us in the May Chemo Club discussion where you can get up date info on all us girls in chemo at the moment. I'm day 10 on first FEC. Looking forward to chatting soon. Nadjie
Posts.Title: chemo starts next week

Posts.Content: Please post to let us know how you got on.  My tips for you post mastectomy - do the exercises religiously even when it hurts to help your recovery and minimise lymphedema.  Also, have clothing planned too.  So, things that are easy to pull up on your bottom half, leggings, loose trousers/skirts with elasticated waistbands.  Also, for your top half, things you can step into are good, cotton vest tops are perfect.  or button up front shirts or cardigans - ie nothing that you have to pull over your head.  For post surgery you will wear a compression bra, after you will need to wear a soft sports like cotton bra for a while.  Asda and Peacocks do great ones reasonably priced.  Sending you best wishes.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic mastectomy with tissue expander and implants... Advice...

Posts.Content: Now thats worth drinking to - congratulations and cheers.
Posts.Title: survivor

Posts.Content: Great to read this Hev and hope all is good with you.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic mastectomy with tissue expander and implants... Advice...

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz.   You are amongst friends.  That radiologist should be sacked, they should not have said anything to you until the results were back.  I remember when I had my scan, they found another two lumps and in my heart I knew it was cancer, but the radiologist did not give anything away.  I'm two weeks post op for a mastecomy with expander reconstruction, so let me know if I can help.  As everyone says it does get easier.  Good luck and eat Easter eggs :-)
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed awaiting appointment

Posts.Content: You're welcome.  I had immediate recon with implant, but they already knew that I didn't have to have radiotherapy as I had already had my lymph node biopsy.  I couldn't have my own tissue - not that I haven't got loads to spare ! - but because I had two C-sections and a hysterectomy.  I am really pleased with my implant and in my bra and clothes you can't tell the difference.  I've also had a nipple recon done and just had my aerola tattooed so am as good as new.  My mastectomy was in March last year so these things take time - I had a temporary expander implant in March and a permanent one in October.    You can have a delayed reconstruction done when your treatment is over, if I was offered radiotherapy I would have accepted it within a heartbeat and left my recon to later.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic mastectomy with tissue expander and implants... Advice...

Posts.Content: Hi Hal53.  If you are going to need radiotherapy then you won't be able to have a mastectomy with implant reconstruction.  That is because the implant gets in the way of the radiotherapy.  That is not the case if you have recon with your own tissue, although obviously you will need to be fully recovered before radiotherapy can begin.  If you don't have lymph nodes involved and they get clear margins with your mastectomy then you may not need radiotherapy, your breast care consultant will be able to advise.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic mastectomy with tissue expander and implants... Advice...

Posts.Content: Hi Ramya I am not sure what my post op care will be yet as i don't have my mastectomy results and won't see the Oncologist till 14th April.  But I can tell you about my experience of reconsruction choice.  I am two weeks post op and I had the one stage expander reconstruction (I am sure there are a number of other names for it).  My experience of recovery has been good.  Yes its sore and painful post op but has got better each day and absolutely doing the exercises is key.  Also, with immediate reconstruction its very important that you take every precaution posiible to avoid infection as this could delay your post op treatment which is more important.  My consultant explained to me that if I got an infection which did not resolve quickly then my implant would have to be removed .  So, my experience is that I've chosen the best reconstruction option for me and two weeks down the line my recovery and movement of my affected arm and area is good.  When maing a reconstruction decision, its important for  your consultant to explain the risks to you, particularly around how it might affect your post op care.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: decisions regarding surgery

Posts.Content: Crystaljuju  surely your statement "BC tumours over 20mm are still curable" is a mistake.  A 20mm tumour is tiny and considered early stage. As per all the comments, early stage means many different things. Best wishes everyone.
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Crystaljuju  surely your statement "BC tumours over 20mm are still curable" is a mistake.  A 20mm tumour is tiny and considered early stage. As per all the comments, early stage means many different things. Best wishes everyone.
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Unless there is good reason why not to, I would take everything that they throw at me.  Like Julia I am Triple Neg so don;t have the luxury of homonal drugs or herceptin. Good luck. Nadjie
Posts.Title: help needed re chemo or not

Posts.Content: Hi Stormy You have had some great advice.  And it is perfectly normal to feel the way you do. It's a big trauma and takes a while to come to terms. Be kind to yourself.  It is much easier to get dressed and undressed (with or without drains) if you don't have to lift clothing over your head.  You don't need to spend a fortune and I got by with strappy vest tops from primark that I stepped into and a couple of baggy cardigans.  My other advice is do the exercises without fail. These will help your recovery enormously.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Having left sided masectomy without reconstruction in 2 weeks, please...

Posts.Content: Hi Mr T Your partner is lucky to have you supporting her and we will support you as we have all been supported here. Its a great community. You are on the road to recovery. Come back on Thursday and tell us how you got on. Don't worry if you forget to ask questions. We'll help you with that and you can call the Breast Cancer Nurse anytime and ask them. As Crystajuju has said the same things you will be told are: 1 The Stage 2 The Grade 3 Whether or not the tumour is hormonal, ie positive to ER, PR and Herceptin 3 The answers from 1-3 will determine pans for treatment, ie surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormonal therapy. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Partner has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Mr T I know you are probably in shock.  But its very common to have chemotherapy etc before surgery and its often very successful in shrinking tumours or them disappearing all together and it means that any surgery after will not be as major.  The waiting and not knowing is the worse and it will be hard not to worry.  But when you know what you're dealing with and the treatment plan you'll feel much more reassured.  You'll get plenty of support on here and we run a monthly chemo club with people about to start or already in chemo.  Myself I have had 4/6 chemos post surgery and there are plenty of people on here that have also had surgery before chemo who will be able to support you. Try if you can to have a nice couple of days enjoying the weather, Sunday and Tuesday will come soon enough. Here's the link to the July chemo club, maybe drop in before you start in August and do let us know how you get on Tuesday. Good luck. Nadjie http://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/38/p/96003/794121.aspx#794121
Posts.Title: Partner has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone I will be dragging myself onto my bike tomorrow to raise funds for Macmillan.  I hope you can find it in your hearts to make a small donation. Here is the link. https://www.justgiving.com/Nadjie-Butler4/ Thank you. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Raising money for Macmillan - New Forest Cycletta - 20 September ...

Posts.Content: H Mr T Good news that you've got the treatement plan because now you can concentrate on getting your girlfriend better.  It is a long time, but I will go quick enough.  There is a monthly chemo club thread that starts evey month, but why don't you pop into the July one where you can get some support on what to expect during chemo and some useful blogs on how to prepare.  Mags22 is there and she's caring for her Mum and you'll also have a ton of other support in there, including me.  Re no reconstruction, I had immediate reconstruction following my mastectomy so I can't help you on that one, but I am sure someone on here can. Take care and be strong. Nadjie PS:  link to July Chemo club is here.
Posts.Title: Partner has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia and Chrissy.  Much appreciated. It was tough but i did it and exceeded my target of £150 so all good. Piccy to follows :-) Thanks again. Nadjie
Posts.Title: Raising money for Macmillan - New Forest Cycletta - 20 September ...

Posts.Content: Chin up Ali, our breast care teams do a great job but things don't always go to plan.  I hope getting it off your chest (pardon the pun) and having support around you will help you get back on track.  On the upside, you don't have to worry about cancer comng back in that breast.  I'm 4 weeks post mastectomy and reconstruction and just like when you first have a crown or implant in your mouth and it feels alien, so your new boob may for a while.  I now feel mine is part me of me although still a while to go and it did take me about 2 weeks before I could actually look it !!!  Good luck.
